35.heading: Breaking Glass.
35.title: The Calculus Affair
35.author: Hergé ; translated by Leslie Lonsdale-Cooper and Michael Turner.
notes: (The Adventures of Tintin)
Translation of L'Affaire Tournesol.

Summary: Captain Haddock accuses Snowy of breaking his priceless Chinese vase and Florentine mirror, but it develops that glass articles are breaking all over the estate. The breakage stops when Professor Cuthbert Calculus leaves his laboratory for Geneva. Foreign agents seem to be aggressively interested, so Tintin, the Captain, and Snowy fly to Geneva to protect the professor. The spies capture the professor, whose invention is the perfection of a powerful weapon. Tintin and Haddock proceed with the chase and rescue. Although Calculus thinks the plans for the weapon are in his umbrella, which Snowy has been keeping track of, he actually left them on the bedside table at home.
Genres: Spy, adventure story.

42.heading: Breaking Horses.
42.title: "Jours de Round-Up" p. 23-33 in Sous le Ciel de l'Ouest
42.author: textes et dessins de Morris, in Lucky Luke : Spécial 2 (Marcinelle-Charleroi, Belgique : Dupuis, 1980).
notes: Summary: It's Spring, and Lucky Luke comes to the Bar 3 ranch looking for a job. If he can break a wild bucking horse named "Polka," he gets the job. Lucky Luke borrows some suspenders, ties himself to the saddle, and the deed is soon done. The work of sorting and branding is accomplished, and a stampede is stopped by Lucky Luke and the Chinese cook. Back at the Bar 3, the owner is concerned to find he has 200 fewer head of cattle than last year. Lucky Luke discovers that two rustlers have been changing the "-3" brand to "4B," and brings them to justice.

112.heading: Breaks.
112.title: "He Caved In on Late-Afternon Soap Opera Breaks"
112.author: Greg & Mort Walker.
notes: Summary: General Halftrack has rejected most of Buxley and Blips's demands.

113.heading: Breaks.
113.title: "He May Mention It Occasionally"
113.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: With a lucky break, Amos has gotten the best of Jake for once, and now the boarders expect to hear about it for a long time.
Key words: Mental judo, yakking.

114.heading: Breaks.
114.title: "His Casts Come Off Next Week"
114.author: by Chris Browne.
notes: Summary: Hagar doesn't like Vikings who can't hold their liquor, but Lucky Eddie says to give him a break.

115.heading: Breaks.
115.title: "I Figure You Owe Him One"
115.author: Stan Lee & Larry Lieber.
notes: Summary: Punisher gave The Owl a break.

117.heading: Breaks.

118.heading: Breaks.
118.title: "Lunch Breaks"
118.author: by Art Spiegelman
118.appears_in: cover of The New Yorker, v. 74, no. 11 (May 11, 1998).
notes: A construction worker is breast-feeding her baby with her lunch pail on the girder next to her.

119.heading: Breaks.
119.title: "Making the Break"
119.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The boy who collected his green apples in baskets gets a chance to sell them; he gets greenbacks and the others just get green around the gills: "You're more likely to get the nod from Lady Luck if you're willing to give her an assist."
Key words: Money, stomach aches. Call no.: PN6726f.B55 "luck"

121.heading: Breaks.

Key words: Underfoot, coffee breaks, salaries, ashes. Call no.: PN6726f.B55 "Salary"

122.heading: Breaks.
